reviewText:
I only played two shifts so far but I am addicted.  Here is my report of the first two days.

Day One:

I started the shift out finding illegal parked cars and writing tickets.  I spent about two hours (game time) doing this when I received a call from dispatch stating there was a report nearby of two people vandalizing a building.  I then turned on my lights and sirens and sped to the location where the report was.  At first I did not find anything as I approched people to gather more information two indvidivauls, a male and female, began to run from me.  I pursued the male on foot calling out to him to him that I was the police and to stop!.  After about a 20 mins foot chase (game time) He finally gave up and I found drug paraphernalia on him and subsequently arrested him.  I radioed dispatch for a van to come take him away to jail.  I then went back to the scene of the crime and found the female not too far away.  She gave up immediately.  I took her into custody and transported her back to the police station.

End of shift

Day 2:

I started off doing speed traps on a rural road for about 3 hours (game time) when I got a transmission from dispatch about a theft that just occured.  I turned on my lights and sirens and arrived at scene to a crying female.  I interviewed her and she gave me an accurate discription of the suspect that took her purse.  I subsequent search of the area I found the male traveling west on the southern most road of town.  I stopped him and idetified myself and he gave up.  I found drugs and further evidence on this subject.  I arrested him and took him to the police station.  After I cleared I noticed a car traveling and a high rate of speed and swerving back and forth.  I activated my lights and sirens and pulled over the car.  The driver was IDed and found that there was problems with his documentation.  I tickted him and cleared the traffic stop.  I then received a call from dispatch of suspcious drug actvity in town.  I then arrived and found the suspected person in the middle of a park.  I walked slowly towards him and IDed myself as a police officer.  The defendeant then pulled a firearm on me and shot twice.  I pulled my service weapon, shot and killed him.  I then called an ambulance to come and clear the scene.

9/10  Would kill drug dealers again

Re-Edit to the trolls* To those trolls who say 1.8 hours.  I am in business and am on the road playing offline more than online.  Offline hours do not count towards my hours played total.  Thanks

reviewText:
Responded code three to an armed robbery in the city. I arrived on scene to two gentlemen fleeing in opposite directions prompting me to give chase. I pull my firearm and demand the suspect to stop, an order he replies too by drawing his own firearm prompting me once again to take action, this time to defend my life and lives of other citizens. I quickly empty my magazine into the suspect to no avail, he must have been using some sort of dark magic or incantation to sheild himself from my rounds as they had no effect on him at point blank range. I retreat, having been hit by the suspect and brought close to the cold death of realistic mode, to cover and grab my MP5 I obviously keep in my back pocket (not complaining, most games do this) and unleash a torrent of bullets.... Once again to no avail... In an attempt not to be killed in the line of duty two hours into my career by an enchanted magic man I sprint to my patrol car while dodging his bullets. Once in my cruiser, I turn on my lights, sirens, and punch the gas in an attempt to run the magic man over.... It only worsened the situation... Once struck by my police car at aproximately 75 MPH the suspect was propelled into orbit, though only for a breif time before he re-entered Earth's atmosphere at super sonic speed and landing on my patrol car (totalling it). Refusing to die to this other worldly being I promptly exited the game so I could respawn in the safety of my home.


While glitches are present in the game, the dedicated staff/developers and their desire to improve the game is comforting. It can get a little monotonous at times but once you step away for an hour or two you can't help yourself from wanting to play more. As long as the staff/developers of this game stay as active as they are (also, if they give us multiplayer and put the game on the Steam Workshop) I have no reason to doubt the potential of this game.

8/10 (mainly due to bugs): Would Patrol Again

reviewText: I hadn't purchased a game for full price in a long while, but was itching to try this one after watching Robbaz's (YouTuber) playthrough for it. I saw that it was on sale via the Humbebundle store for $14.99, so I purchased it there.\n\nThe game is really fun, and if you like police simulators at all, you will enjoy this game - I will continue to play it and see how it develops. Unfortunately, however, I have to leave this at a do not recommend
date: because I feel very disappointed at the product I was presented with. The simplest way for me to have given Enforcer a thumbs up
recommended:
would be for the developers to have this labelled as an early access/beta game. As an avid game reviewer, I CANNOT support this type of presentation. I have a fairly massive backlog of games in my library left to review (on top of my backlog of games to play), but I decided to bump this up to the very top, because I want as many people to avoid making the mistake I made in buying this game AND believing it to be a final, finished product. I went ahead and tried it out despite many of the negative reviews, but I implore everyone and anyone interested to wait to see whether or not the game actually develops further.

Because quite obviously, this is a largely unfinished, barebones product. It both plays and feels like an early access game, and I would know, since I had a pretty potent early access game phase. Unlike the cesspool that is Starbound, I sincerely hope that the developers for Enforcer continue to work on the game, as it definitely has a lot of potential.

Now, on to the meat of the review.

The aesthetics are good, the detail in the environment and character models are decent. The rain effects are pretty weak, and there the vehicle damage is insignificant. There seems to be a very low pool of character models, with the main difference being the color of their outfits. The vehicle pool is also considerably tiny, and you will notice this very quickly. The sounds and music are average, but I prefer to play my own instead. While in your police cruiser, there will be chatter over the radio, but (again) that pool appears to also be small, so you will notice repetitions within the first hour of playing.

The controls may take a bit of effort to get used to - there is a pop-up help menu right when you begin, and a super quick tutorial after you select your character sex and name. The help menu also provides descriptions for most of the things you can currently do in the world, and I strongly recommend you take a look through everything to properly orient yourself in the Enforcer world. The learning curve is minimal to moderate, depending on your experience with police simulators. You can play the game on normal or realistic mode, the latter having permanent death and more rapid/frequent missions for you to do.

I've played this game quite a bit and enjoyed it a lot, however, many of the game elements show the unpolished quality common in early access game builds. For example, the AI is very basic, and many times you might ask a car to pull over, only to have them rear-end another car. Of course, the sloppiness of the AI will fool you, as this event will NOT constitute as an offence of any sort (at least on top of whatever offence that particular NPC might already have committed). I've seen a car speed through a red light and drive straight into a civilian crossing the street (not hurting the walker in any way, oddly enough) and - after pulling him over - the only recorded offence was speeding.

When you pull over vehicles - you can do so by toggling your cruiser's warning siren, or calling out on foot - you will be given a few options like: apply breathalyzer, write ticket, and check license and registration (this will show you any offences the driver has committed). Something I don't really like about the latter feature is that you can set up traffic cones to create a roadblock, then go through an endless lineup of cars and spam the check license and registration" option. Even if the car had been speeding blocks away from you

reviewText:
I regret having to give this game a thumbs down, because I really do think it could have been something. In it's current state, it isn't worth the $20 price tag. The game lacks content and gets boring real fast. At this moment, there is only ONE developer working on this game. In the discussion threads, the developer explains that to him, this game is complete, and basically everything from now on is just icing on the cake...WOW... This game is basically an alpha...if that. I understand the whole small team, low budget thing, but to say this game is, in any way complete, is just plain crazy.

PROS:
+Can be entertaining in small bursts.
+Sandbox
+The game does have potential (maybe not anymore, but it did).
+It has an aspect of realism to it.
+The updates are free (as they should be), and the developer stated he didn't want DLCs.
+Developers respond to you if you ask a question or comment on something.
+Pretty cool customization of your police unit. You can also purchase things like a new flatscreen or a couch for your house with your hard earned cash, which is sweet.

CONS:
-Bugs/Glitches (apparently not enough to be game breaking as the game is completed--spoken by developer)
-Stiff movement system for driving and on-foot. Frustrating controls.
-Poor animations.
-GTA 3 graphics.
-Not enough content to warrant a $20 price tag. It needs more missions/guns/cars/skins/buildings/everything.

I really wish this game had more fans and a workshop, because that would change things. More content, better graphics/animations, more skins/customization, would add to the longevity of the game. At the state that this game is in, I cannot recommend this title.

Verdict: 5/10

reviewText:
This is clearly a game with a relitively low budget, but still is a very fun police simulator and, in my opinion, worth the money. In this review I will assess the positives and negatives, explain some of the features and finally give my verdict on the game.

Positives:

- Variety of different missions (passive and direct).
- 7 regions to explore.
- On and Off Duty modes.
- Level up / Ranking system in the police force.
- Can interact with every NPC civilian.
- Police cars have warning sirens, full sirens, and lightbars that can be customised.
- Variety of clothing and vehicle paintjobs.
- Realistic feel of policing.
- Can storm buildings, make civilians surrender, stop fleeing vehicles by hitting them with yours.
- Has an easy and hard mode.

Negatives:

- At the time of its release, it is quite buggy.
- When an ambulance / police transport / tow truck is called, they are not actually seen.
- Car physics are not very realistic.
- You get reduced career points for actions such as breaking down doors even if there is a criminal inside.
- You are the only patrol officer in the game.
- Fleeing NPCs act as if they were not being chased if they get clear of you a few metres, then run again when you get close.
- Limited things to do Off Duty.
- Does not have a very comrehensive help / controls screen.
PLEASE NOTE MANY OF THE ABOVE WILL MOST LIKELY BE IMPROVED / FIXED AS THE GAME DEVELOPS!

Suggestions:

- Could have custom loadouts (e.g. different weapons).
- Could call backup such as a SWAT team.
- When the player reaches a high rank, they could command other officers.
- Needs more vehicles and Off Duty activities (could maybe respond to specific emergencies).

Analysis:

I am someone who is a big fan of police simulators. Arma 3 Altis Life was great for this, and Enforcer: Police Crime Action is quite similar, only it is single player. You can drive around the town centre looking out for speeders (cars drive around 20mph and around 30mph is considered speeding) and you can pull them over, use the breathalyser or frisk them if you feel it is necessary. On the start of every shift there is a passive mission to complete by the end of the shift, for example setting up a roadblock with cones and checking 6 drivers for faults on their cars. There are also dispatch calls with generous time limits such as finding a person wanted for assaulting passers by. For this you would go and talk to the victims to get a description, then wait until there is intel about where the person was last seen. You would then go to the scene, find the person matching the description, and park up. Normally when you call out for them to stop, they will run off. You can pull out your tazer, and when you get close you fire. After that you can arrest the suspect, take them to the station or call for a transport. You get career points which help you rank up after completing every mission.

Off duty mode is really unique, and has a lot of potential. When you have enough money you can buy a car, and you can also customise your home with new furniture. It is also possible to level up your stress level buy going out with friends or your mother, and other people. Instead of actually interacting with your friends or mother, the game teleports you to their house and puts the time forward a few hours, and says that you have spent time with your friends / mother, without you actually seeing anything. Physically doing activities may well be something the developers add in the future. When off duty it is also possible to fill up on food and replenish your energy by sleeping. You have to be careful though as spending too much time off duty will reduce career points.

Conclusion:

This game as mentioned earlier has obviously been developed on a low budget, but they have made that budget stretch as far as possible. The gameplay is enjoyable even though the graphics and physics are not fantastic. Now it has been released, it is likely that if lots of people buy it and the developers have access to more money, the game will be better optimized, feel more smooth and have some great new features added. That will of course come over time so if anything, the money you put in to buy this game will be an investment, so they can improve it. That said, even before the game is developed further it is still great fun and I can see a lot of hours of gameplay from it.

Overall Verdict:

I would recommend this game to any fan of police simulators, or anyone who fancies a go at being a police officer. It may at first seem very rough and strange, but believe me, you will probably get used to it just fine.

I rate Enforcer: Police Crime Action 7/10 at its current state but it has the potential of being a 8/10 or even 9/10 game.

reviewText: Great idea, poor execution. An open world sandbox police 'sim' is something i've wanted to play since the likes of Police Quest. And this game pretty much has that idea down. Unfortunately, it's let down by its execution. The graphics and animation are poor, worse than GTA 3. The AI is all but non existant. All NPC criminals either run from you, give up, or stand in one spot and slowly shoot at you. Pathfinding is poor - pedestrians will mindlessly walk into anything blocking their path forever. The physics are poor. Cars don't crash so much as 'stop'. Hitting a tree, building, or even a pedestrian will cause your car to stop on a dime. Other vehicles also have a tendency to fly into the air randomly.\n\nIf this was early access, I'd say wait and see, but as a fully released title? Sorry, can't reccomend it especially for the price they're asking.

reviewText: This game at it's current form demands a lot of patience from the person that plays it. Most of the AI is very underdeveloped: pedestrians walking everywhere, stoping for nothing and nobody. The driving in the game is a nightmare. Speed is a relative term at the moment, getting from 20mph to 134mph under a second... and good luck stoping... without immidiate reversing. Missions are quite repetative but so is the life of a police officer... as I would imagine.The time passes real quick. An hour in the game equals to a minute in our life not leaving much space to complete missons without doing 16 hours shifts. The concept of getting hungry, tired and irritated is a great idea, but at the moment they don't have much effect on our character. Ranking up is also a great idea... yet again, doesn't really change much. You are still putting those speeding cameras out, regardless your rank. But enough of the negatives.\nIt's a police simulator! Yes. You are wearing a uniform, you have your police cruiser, which is by the way very nicely detailed, as far as sound and lights go. The weapon mechanics is acceptable and it is fun giving out those tickets for broken lights or  speeding thorugh town to attend a burglary.\nThe developers have a great vision. There is no doubt about it. This game might have been released just a bit too early, but their presence in forums and announcments on up-coming updates is reassuring that buying this game at this price is an investment. Now it is up to us if we are willing to invest and see the development through. I am, because it's exciting to be part of developing a great police simulator.

reviewText:
My biggest problem with this game is that it feels like a very early access inide game and no where near like the complete product.

Firstly the driving mechanics are aweful the controls feel clunky, it feels like driving a tank and you even have to turn off the engine before you are allowed to get out of the car. I don't think they will fix this either because it is one of the core mechanics of the game.

Unfortunatly when you do anything it is done through a menu system, for example you call to get a prisoner transport and instead of seeing a car come out and pick up the prisiner you get a screeen shot saying it has been done, this is the same for ambulances, tow trucks ect.

The graphics leave a lot to be desired, most of the game looks pretty poor the models look like they came out of a ps1 game, this would not be an issue if the game mechanics were better. Also every citezen looks the same i think there are no more than say 10 character models.

The map is split into tiny sections you have to drive through checkpoints to get to different parts of the map, there are so many loading screens in this game for pretty much everything you do.

All the above points are things that are core parts of ther game and will probably never be changed/fixed at the time of writing there are many other issues too such as bugs (cars floating in the sky), I feel like the duty time is too short it makes you rush to complete the day, buying yoyur own car is far too expensive compared to how much money you make, you have to get a taxi home because home is too far from the station. Hopefully the modding community will come to the rescue of this game but at the moment i wouldn't recommend this game, ive played played games that cost £4 - £5 that have been more polished  and genrally better games.

reviewText:
II have been looking for a game like this for a long time but I guess my search will have to go on.

Looks like this game is based on Police Mod for GTA IV. It offers you plenty of options what can a good officer do, like patrolling the streets, stopping cars, checking drivers, chasing burglars and vandals.

You always play in the sandbox mode and you have to watch your needs (hunger, energy, health). You have to complete some of the missions during duty hours (some of them are optional and randomly generated) but it gets very repetitive very soon.

Technical side of the game is a problem. City looks empty and sterile. You see some pedestrians on the streets but they all looks the same (only few types).

Driving mechanics is also bad, it feels nothing like any of the GTA games.

For the standard price I cannot recommend this game, fair price would be 10 Euro.

reviewText:
At first this game is amazing, then it gets predictable and repititive.

This game is not finished. The developers seem to be working on it. It seems like an early access game.  Part of this game is not really realistic, Like responding to a robbery. They ALWAYS escape on foot. A red circle follows the suspect, even if you have not arrived yet.

You do these following things over and over:
1)Give parking tickets
2)Stop drunk drivers/arrest
3)Inspect license and vehicle/ticket
4)Go to drug dealers (arrest or shoot)
5)Go to hostage situation (arrest or shoot)

I would say 7 hours maxes out replay value. I would not spend $20, only $10 (its half off right now) with the condition there is going to be at least 25% more content.

Good:
This is the only cop game I am aware of.
It makes me feel sorry for cops.
Realistic mode= one life. If you die, you die. Like being a cop in real life!
Fun, until you figure the mechanics out and can predict everything.
I got nervous because somebody pulled out their cell phone and I thought it was a gun +++
High speed chases during routine traffic stops
I ask for somebody to open the door, they do, they have a weapon, I blast them away +++
Shooting bad guys (especially on realistic mode) +++

Bad:
No randomness, easily predicatable
You can't call backup.
Bad guys are only activated one at a time if you get in their vincinity
Can't see where bullets are coming from
NO BODY ARMOR REALLY??!
Promotions are not very valuable at all.
Not enough upgrades
Fun goes downhill fast

reviewText:
DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY. This game leaves a lot to be desired and honestly feels like an early release at best. It absolutely is NOT worth the $19.99 at this point in its production and will need many large updates to make it anywhere close to worth its asking price. I will list some pros and cons:

Pros:
-It's a police simulator and those are hard to come by, if nothing else it's an attempt to deliver a very demanded but rare game format
-It's ambitious: There are many features such as buying police cars, living life off work, etc. which are nice on first play
-Practial button layout

Cons:
-Really, really clunky - the car driving and handling may be some of the worst I've ever tried. Sure having features such as having to turn on the engine and the realistic idle movement of drive and reverse are fun in theory, but the steering controls manage to be un and/or late responsive while the gas and reverse are over-responsive. It's horrible. Running and crouching aren't much better.
-This game doesn't look pretty. I get that it's not a large studio producing it but if you're going to charge me $20 at least have more than five car and character models in the game
-Everyone in this game has a gun. I have done 10 missions and 9/10 ended with the suspect pulling a gun
-Shooting controls are very poor - the gun often will not fire the first few shots unless you zoom in, which can lead to getting you killed
-Boring mission types - There are a variety of missions and the idea of questioning suspects and searching nearby buildings is a great one, but the tips are only clothing descriptions and all the searches end in you having to gun down a pistol wielding suspect
-Simple features such as tow trucks, ambulance calls, and police pick up lack an animation and instead take you to a brief load screen before returning you to where you were witht he action performed - things like this REALLY make it feel like an early access
-Whoever developed it is not an English speaker and google translate is not flawless. Many spelling or wording mistakes really prevent it from having a professional, clean feal

In conclusion, don't buy this game. I was incredibly disappointed with this game. I was quite excited that a new police simulator was finally being produced as there are barely any available. Don't get me wrong, I know it is a small project and wouldn't be upset if this were an early release, but I paid a decent price for it for far from a decent product. On the very bare outside it looks similar to LCPDFR, but don't be fooled. This game is far from being worth its asking price and will need some serious updating in the control, mission, and visual department before it comes close its asking price.

reviewText: Cool idea, badly made. This game at this stage is not worth buying it especially not as a release version. It has some really nice implementations like choosing your patrol vehicle and customizing it. Also the missions are fun. BUT sadly this game is so full of bugs and annoyances that I can't recommend it right now. If even slowly driving your patrol vehicle onto the concrete of the downtown gas station damages your car badly (up to 10%), that's just not how it should be. Also the handling while driving is annoying. The slightest push of a button can completely turn your car around. Not to mention all the bugs like flying cars that are not reachable which makes it impossible to finish certain missions, too fast decreasing of gas and car condition, clipping errors (eg. handling your submachine gun), invisible road bumps that crash your car and so on. As said, the idea behind the game is pretty cool, once the developers flat out MANY bugs and annoyances, it might be actually pretty fun. Until then, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
This game is not a full game. It handles like an early developed mod. It was created for the ground up so as a single developer, this is something to be proud of. However, as a game that claims to be full, it is not even close. There are many areas that are lacking. Many features that were promised that still have yet to show up. The player movement is clunky, car acceleration random and almost uncontrolable, useful customization almost non existant, features that felt like dead ends and were started but never finished. The world feels so empty, and you have such a large area to patrol, I feel like this should be state patrol or sheriff's department. It's so empty. You are the ONLY COP.

This is not a complete game. If you're desperate for a police game, ok buy this, but other than that? Don't waist your money. Get GTA IV for $20 and downloand the mod LCPDFR. Its clunky and crashes, but it still feels more complete than this game. You can download additional callouts, bug fixes, custom cars, custom uniforms, different scripts for police AI, the possibilities are endless...

Unfortunately this game just falls short. If I knew anything about developing I would totally help this guy out and crank out an awesome and complete game. This game has potential, but a year after launch? Still feels empty and incomplete.

In this current state, I would not recommend it.

reviewText: This game is suprisingly fun for me to play even when not much is happening. The graphics are not the best but they don't take away too much from the gameplay, plus the game came out pretty recently so I'm sure a lot of bugs will be fixed and things added. It's a pretty realistic simulator, as you get rewarded in points for giving out tickets correctly, capturing criminals, and helping out people, and you lose points for arresting innocent people, police abuse, civilian casualties, etc. And as you get points you get promoted, which earns you a larger salary each time you complete a shift, and you can buy items for your house, cars, gas, food, and ammo. You have three meters (stress, energy, and hunger) which you can replenish while off duty or on duty, but you get penalized for staying off duty too long, and you can stay on duty as long as you want as long as you have enough energy. The animations are pretty good for each action like walking, asking questions, hand cuffing, etc. and the only bad part of the animations is the idle animation for you character, as he/she just stands there lik a ragdoll and slightly breathes, and some of the animtion transitions are jumpy but still pretty good. It kinda reminds me of Watch_Dogs except you are the cops and no hacking, but is still fun. You still get some fun out of this despite some bugs and overall apearance, but again, the game is new and I'm sure will be fixed and imporved in time. If you take a look at the news feed on this game, you can see that they are frequently updating and have laid out plans for the future, and I think now might be a good time to get this game so you can get a feel for it and watch it improve, and plus you get a free soundtrack. (If you like that kind of stuff...) I guess you could mess around and just arrest everyone, but i'm not sure if you can lose" the game yet unless you have realism mode on. Trust me
date: this game is going to go far
recommended: don't let the appearence fool you..."

reviewText:
So far this is the best *dedicated police sim* available. If you are a fan of LCPD:FR, you'll love this - it's more refined and less glitchy. It is not without bugs and glitches however, but once you accept that 1. It's the first day of release, 2. It's their first PC game on the market and 3. The team consists of 4 devs you really appreciate the work that has been put into it (especially if you've been following the game since it was first announced like I have).

Some feedback I would like to give the devs:
1. Currently certain areas in the roads are buggy, making your car flip at high speed, or just hit invisible objects.

2. The cars could be a bit more durable - police cruisers (particularly the Crown Vic) are known for their ability to take a lot of punishment, at current time i lose about 2-4% of vehicle health by going over small bumps at the gas station.

3. I'd love to hear more variety in the police radio clips, currently the clips are from the NYPD and as such reference New York locations, it'd be awesome to get voice actors in to record some radio, or at least grab a few more clips.

4. Change the hunger animation, or remove it. I don't have a problem with the animation, but it'd be better if it only played once - when the hunger bar drops right down and from then on only having the text notification. I get what it's trying to achieve, and i like it: but at crucial times (foot pursuits, shootouts) it's annoying to have to stop for 3 seconds for the animation to play, leaving you very vulnerable.

Some things I'd like to see added in the future:
1. More player customisation (especially some kind of Sheriff / State Trooper uniform)
2. More NPC variety
3. An extra civilian car or two (perhaps a charger for about $25,000)
4. Perhaps a police motorcyle (and proper uniform of course) for more highway patrol type players.

For anyone who has actually read this far, you should definitely get the game if you're into police sims - the devs are very open and actually listen to our feedback, so give it a play and tell them (constructively) what you think - at $14.99 until the end of October you really can't go wrong!

reviewText:
A great concept, but sloppy execution. Think of True Crime New York City; you could give tickets, inspect cars, frisk people, etc. However, like True Crime NYC, this game is rather broken. The world feels empty, the NPCs are nearly identical aside from a few color differences in clothing, there is a lack of dialogue. In all aspects, the game can be done if you look past these things but it really needs a lot of work. The aimming is clunky, the driving is dodgy, the weather effects are ugly.

There is no denything that I still enjoyed the game. However, until the game is polished up, I will not be touching this game for a while. There are many ways the player can boost, or outright manipualte the way the game is meant to be played and quickly level up. Despite the bugs and exploits, you can have a fun time but the game can get really boring really fast, there's not much to do when off-duty.

In conclusion, if you can look past the bugs and exploits, you will most likely like this game if you enjoy police simulators. However, if you are like me and suffer from strong OCD, the glitches will really drive you insane. If and when this game is a little bit more playable, I will indeed consider rewriting my review. Great concept, fun at times, but it needs a lot of work.
6.5/10.

reviewText:
I do not write a lot of reviews, but I feel this simulator needs one. I'm not going to review the story line, but just the gameplay itself. Enforcer: Police Crime Action centres around a single municipal police officer in a small desert town. You respond to call the dispatch informs you about and you have the options to respond to the calls or not. There is also real-time events happening in the city as well. It likes to focus mostly around the every day duties of a police officer and it does this very well. The simulator also goes beyond the duties of a police officer and you have to maintain you social and home life when you are not on duty, like manage your stress, eating, sleeping, and spending time with friends and family. Now that I have vaguely explained the game, I'm going to go into pros and cons of the game.

Pros:
-The simulator/game, or whichever you prefer to call it, does an amazing job of immersing you into the life of a police officer. The lackluster graphics still do not get in the way of making you feel and believe you are the law enforcement of this town and tries to make you thorough in your investigations and arrests, making you feel like you want to make a difference in the one-cop-town.

-The callouts. There is, at this stage of the game, quite a few different types of callouts that dispatch will give you while you're driving aroung town, looking for any law breakers. You can do simple things like, stopping some delinquents from vandalizing a public building to solving a kidnapping and finding the kidnapped and taking out the kidnapper and calling in an ambulance to take the kidnapped person from the situation.

-The rank up system. There is a huge list of different ranks to go through, from just a simple patrol officer to the chief of police. The list is quite large and every crime you solve and even just giving an illegally parked car a ticket helps you earn points to rank up and earn new things, like different police vehicles and customization items to them, as well as making your paycheck at the end of each shift more bountyfull.

-Being able to make vehicle roadblocks and checkpoints, for example, like creating a drunk driving program where you stop vehicles and perform breath tests to catch drunk drivers and even inspect vehicles to make sure they are road-worthy. Even just doing this can add enjoyment of feeling like a police officer and busting those damn drunk drivers a ticket and time in the slammer.

-The game does balance the action and simulation very well. I have had to chase down many suspects that attemted to flee and deploy the tazer on them, watching them get the jitters and then give themselves up after one hell of a shocking. You are equipped with a pistol and a SMG when there are those times that you just can't take them down the nonlethal way. I found myself hiding behind my vehicle helplessly as the offender continues to sling lead my direction and found myself trying to figure out how to take him down and end the situation.

I could name many more Pros to this game, but I may edit those in at a later time, but let's address the obvious Cons of this game now.

Cons:
-The graphics are horrendous, but given the small team that made this whole game themselves, you find yourself not caring too much, but this is a Con because the optimization is pretty bad. For a game that lack a lot of detail in the town there shouldn't be an excuse why I only get less than 20FPS on the medium settings on my system. The optimization is really bad and I run a pretty good system, so I should get 30FPS or more on the medium setting.

-Physics are non-existing. You are, what feels like, stuck to the ground, like your car is a giant magnet and stuck to the ground. There's really not much else to say about the physic-less world, but let's hope there is some sort of physic engine added in later, probably much later.

-The controls, oh the controls, they are awful, with no sensitivity sliders, or custom key options. You turn your car almost 90 degrees by just barely tapping the A" and "D" keys. It makes it hard to stay to one side of the road and you find yourself all over the damn road and crashing into everything.

-Damage system. Your car takes way too much damage easily. Just by bumper tapping or hitting curb

reviewText:
Enforcer is one of those games you have to take a chance on to enjoy. The graphics are bad, its really outdated looking for a 2014 game and the driving engine is handmade in Hell. However, the gameplay is there in spades - fans of Maxis' SimCopter will be at home here.

You play a uniformed cop who simply works a shift and is faced with mundane tasks like setting up speed cameras to record speeding vehicles, or chasing down armed suspects after a botched home invasion. You can ask a suspect to comply while you check his ID, frisk him for weapons or arrest him, and use your radio to have him taken downtown or have his vehicle towed, all with an intuitive interface.

The missions are quite repetitive and if you're quick to complete them, you can face a boring period of wandering around looking for speeders or drunk drivers while waiting for an official" mission. However
date: if you like police themed games

reviewText:
First I will start this review by touching on the admins of the game here on Steam. Quite frankly they are terrible with customer service, after asking a simple question one of their admins gave a short response (did not answer the question) then proceeded to lock the thread. Not the best way to handle a customer.

The game itself has its high and low points. Despite what the designers state, it does feel a little repetitive no matter how you play the game. The limited customization of characters, the fact that characters don't have traits upon creation or their experiences working make the player character feel bland. The personal interactions are also very bland and don't do much to bring the player into the world of the officer they are playing.

Enforcer does provide a large playing area where you can explore, yet the world feels a bit empty. In a day and age with so much attention paid to how Police Officers perform their job, you do not get any of this in the game. You do not even have other officers, events that change how the community sees the police, or a Chief that imposes training on the force.

Unfortunately, it causes the game to feel a bit hollow. While you have the option to choose from a number of police vehicles, and freedom to patrol where you want, there's just a great deal missing that causes the game to not feel satisfying.  I am recommending the game only based on the fact it's the only one of its kind and it's not terrible if you have low expectations.

The developers also should take a hard look at how they respond to customers as well.

True Score: 5.5/10

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential in it, however the dev's have abandoned this game. They promised updates since June then nothing was heard until August, and now nothing. I had hope that this game would get the needed updates to make it more playable however that doesn't seem like it will ever happen.

The game becomes quite repetitive with the few calls in-game (and if you ever get one) and the energy system that hardly gets you through one patrol. The visuals are ok for the most part but could use some touching up. The main issues with this game are the physics and the animations. I can understand that this is an indie game and I'm not expecting AAA game quality but you shouldn't bounce off into space when you get rear ended by the AI.

Overal if this game had the key issues fixed and if the price was lower I could recommend it, however with its current state and being thrown into the trash by the dev's I can not recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend or even suggest this to anyone. When it came out it had a lot of promise with a dev team that would interect with the players on the forums, addressing bugs and even trying to put in mod support. The content was growing with new vehicles, a reworked and revamped map, and albeit it isn't content, bug fixes.

Then it stopped, promises of a huge patch that would add a lot more content and bug fixes was constantly pushed off. They would even start silencing the steam forum of any sort of dissent and eventually the communication stopped. After a bit of a lull they finally came up with a date to expect it. And when the time came, nothing. They addressed it again, gave it another date and once more, nothing.

This game showed a lot of promise, considering that there isn't much of a market for Law Enforcement Simulators or even games.  Heck it even had a skeptic like me thinking that they could pull it off.

The game in its current state is better then it was when launched, but still retains some of the odd bugs paired with its awkward driving controls and weird AI, you would swear you leapt from the Alpha test to the beginning stages of Beta testing. As for the customization, you can change the skin on your police car and your uniform...and that's it.

Although, I may have been gifted this game. I feel nothing but awful for having recieved it knowing that they have willingly spent money on this with the goodness of their heart.

If you wish to pursue another Police Simulator, I would recommend that you purchase GTAV and download the LSPDFR mod. The difference is considerable. Especially due to the customization of the LSPDFR Mod that allows you to improve your Law Enforcement experience.

reviewText:
I supported Enforcer during its infancy, when it was actually known as Police Tactics. The developers were friends of mine on a forum, and I eagerly expected the release. The trailers provided a great insight into what we could be doing when the game was officially released; however, it seems the actual product wasn't really portrayed very well.

Enforcer: Police Crime Action delivers a fun and different experience with its gameplay:
You have an off duty lifestyle, tied into the game with an actual need (Stress level). While it's not really superbly fun and you can't spend more than a few hours off duty before getting bored, it's a cool feature.

Being on duty involves multiple 'tasks' in which you do not have to finish but increase your career points, leading to promotions. These tasks can be anything from pulling over a required amount of vehicles within a certain amount of time  to call-outs, robberies and drunks being just a few.

Vehicle customization is a neat addition, offering four different vehicles (two are unlocked via secret codes, obtained by registering your game) all with their own liveries. Lightbars, light colours and wheel types are also some of the changeable options.

To experience the features, you really must watch a gameplay. Of course, being a police officer, a day is never the same, and you have to watch someone play it to see this.

Of course, as it's only a first release, bugs are to be expected, but this game has started very poorly. Driving needs a hell of a lot of fine-tuning, it feels clunky and not at all fluid. The entire game is sort of clunky; it plays very much the indie game it is. If you're looking for an LCPD:FR contender, you're not going to find it. LCPD:FR expanded on a triple A game engine, fully developed and rounded off by Rockstar; Odin Game Studio has built this game from the ground up and it stands as a completely different game. LCPD:FR has the advantage of calling in backup, more vehicles, an urban environment, backup, etc, whereas Enforcer is somewhat primitive in this approach, featuring no backup and only a crude radio to call in prisoner transport (this is executed via a loading screen), but I feel after many updates the realism will shoot up, making the game a more immersive experience than it currently is.

The usual bugs are found, odd animations, cars flying everywhere, but these don't really affect gameplay too much (they did on the first release; gunfights were a mess!),, and provide a few laughs. It is a bit annoying, though.

As it stands, Enforcer: Police Crime Action needs a lot of work, but if we do get that, it could easily be worth its £14.99 asking price.

reviewText:
Well overall to summarise on this game, if you enjoy being a cop then go for it, especially if you havent played a cop simulator game before.
As i got into it i was enjoying it, seemed quite new and refreshing, with placing speed cameras, traffic cones, stopping traffic, breathalising drivers, checking for damage etc. Then you got the missions that come up suddenly like theres been a report of a robbery so you have to investigate and catch the suspect(s).
But so far into the game, this is pretty much all i've done. You start off as a police officer rank and work your way upto chief of police, and in the help guide in the game, it says as you progress ranks you unlock new missions and therefore take on more challenging and complex jobs. Yet this hasnt been the case, as i'm now a Lieutenant and i'm still doing the same jobs (getting the same jobs) that i've been given since the start and its now all too repetetive.

So to sum up for me...i good game, different. But longetivity doesnt seem to be there for me, as i just keep getting the same missions despite having been promoted ranks and i'm now not too far off the top rank as lieutenant. Maybe someone else will back me up on this or reassure me that new missions do come up once you progress from lieutenant.
Bit disappointing in this respect but a decent game. I'd recommend buying it when on discount.

reviewText:
Edit: keep in mind I made this review a decent amount of time ago, some of the problems have been fixed such as your car getting damaged while entering places like the gas station after the map was entirely redesigned, however many other problems mentioned still persist
Let me start off by saying this game shows potential, however with that beign said, this game is not a finished product.
The game has a number of problems that need to be fixed before it can truly be considered a worthwhile purchase
one of the first problems I noticed while playing the game is that, at least in the starting region, driving onto the platform for the gas station will damage your car, there is literally no way around this from what I have seen, this also occurs in other locations around the city such as the repair station (or whatever it is called). Furthermore the missions are often rather repetative as the criminals will often spawn in the same locations every time. In addition there is literally no incentive to bring the criminals back alive (if they have their gun drawn) you recieve the same points for killing the criminal as you do for brining them back alive (unless they dont have their gun drawn, points are lost for shooting at them).  As well despite the several distinct regions in the game, they all feel almost entirely bland as they are rife with either unenterable buildings, or land with nothing on it. Another thing that I must complain about is the fact that shooting vehichles does literally NOTHING, if you shoot at a vehichle it will not do any damage to the vehichle or the driver, also problamatic is the fact that if you shoot at a civilian vehichle, no points are deducted. Another problem is that if you simply quit and reload your game, your stress level will be reset and your sleep and hunger levels are also almost enitrely reset, which removes the necessity to take anytime off. There are also rampant glitches, such as the fact that the main city (or at least the one your house is in the region of) is rife with invisible potholes on the streets that will do damage to your car if you go over them at too high a speed and possibly even send your vehichle flying. As well I have noticed sometimes that there will randomly be vehichles just sort of floating in the air. I have also noticed that sometimes in the city various vehichles will run into each other for no apparent reason, maybe it is just the drunk drivers but I dont know.
Overall, I think that if the problems with this game are fixed it could be a good or maybe even a great game, I really do like the concept of a game where you play as a police officer as it has not been done very often, however until they fix the problems listed and the many more that I probably didnt notice or think to write about, then it is not really a worthwhile purchase
UPDATE: they are improving the game however, so hopefully soon they will fix the bugs that currently plague the game

reviewText:
While I've seen more than a few rather negitive reviews on this game, I'd like to add to the growing pool of positive ones.

This game lacks a certain polish -- it almost reminds me of the old GTA or Driver games, yet has a sincere charm to it. It's a great concept (as mods for GTA V such as LCPD:FR have shown with their massive fanbase), and this actually isn't a bad excution of it, while it needs some serious bug-hunting and polish, the potential is certainly there.

Problems:
1.) Days are way too short, you don't have time to do much, then your character is clutching his guts in agony while standing in the road.
2.) Time compression is extreme, gas runs out, hunger sets in, and your character becomes lethargic all while driving to work.
3.) Physics are non-existent, one stop light in particular sends cars flipping across the road, good entertainment value, but certainly immersion breaking.

The good stuff:
1.) I think a game like this has had a demand for some time now, while we've seen a few teasers over the years they've often turn to little more than a flash in the pan, unless you count the CoD clone SWAT games (police=FPS... wut?).
2.) The game-play is rather straight forward, and the Sims-esque needs give you a break after putting the hurt on drunk drivers for a couple hours. I know after playing GTA V with LCPD:FR for a couple hours, I often got bored and started a massive killing spree -- no reason to do that here.
3.) Options: car liveries, and player clothing. You have several asthetic options right off the bat, all of which seem to have had work and thought put into them.
4.) The future -- I think this game will get the polish it needs, the devs are small enough to work with their potential fanbase, and although I haven't had look at the files yet, probably has a good modability factor.

I know what you're asking and why you're reading this: Red
date: should I buy this game with my hard-earned money?"\nWell
recommended: I really couldn't tell you -- while the potential is there

reviewText: Ever since I heard about this game, I was very excited for it to be released. I bought it the day it came out, and I think it was worth the 15 dollars I spent on it, but maybe not the full price. At least not yet. The game still needs a lot of work, but I appreciate that the developers are working hard to fix all the issues with the game. I'm not sure how quickly it will be fully fixed, but when it is, this game will be really great. For example, I am still having issues with cars flying in the air, and a lot of pop in. I'll be driving down the road and sometimes objects will just appear right infront of me. This makes it almost impossible to drive through town without almost totalling my car each time. I also am still having a lot of issues with lag. If I was playing a game like Skyrim on Ultra I might question if my computer can handle it, but with this game, I'm pretty sure it still needs to be optimized for more graphical set ups. I have a quad core and radeon duel graphics, so I think I should be able to handle this just fine... Any ways, once all the issues are worked out this game could be a lot of fun. I'll still thumbs up it because I have faith it will get better!

reviewText:
I want to make this review short and sweet since this game is hardly worth my time to review, however I find it my duty as a gamer to ward off people hoping to buy this piece of ♥♥♥♥.

---------------------------------------------

First off: It's plagued with bugs. Flying cars, glitching NPCs, falling through the earth, getting stuck in the ground or buildings, failing an objective despite completing it with flying colours, hell some objectives won't complete at all and you'll be stuck in a state of boredom limbo.

Secondly: The game is horrendously boring, so far I've only experienced 5 different events multiple times, and 2 flavours of side activity. Most of the time will be spent mining trading cards or waiting for the off chance that you actually get given an objective that you haven't completed 50 times previously.

Thirdly: The team has abandoned it completely. They are nowhere to be found except in their miserable fiefdoms, moderating their forum with an iron fist like a Cold War era Russian dictator. They don't listen to it's player base, they don't update their game, they break all of their promises and they have the *gall* to insult players with actual concerns, actual criticisms and actual desires to see this game completed.

---------------------------------------------

In summary, stay away from this mess, the game is broken and it won't be fixed and the development team are petulant children not deserving of a single cent from you.

If you want a police simulator, you're better off getting the First Response mods for GTAIV or V.

reviewText:
Let me start this review off by saying that this game has its quirks, but also has a peculiar charm that keeps making me come back to play it. While it has a lot of fun things to do, it currently is quite buggy, which the developers have promised to fix in patches, along with new features in the next few months. So here are the pros:

- Has a fun concept; patrol the town and surrounding country looking for criminals or traffic violations.
- Different dispatch missions; various calls like drunks causing trouble, robberies etc.
- Multiple ways of catching criminals; tasers, guns, shout at them to surrender etc.
- You can kick people's doors in an arrest them with a warrant (this is buggy at the moment tho)

Cons:
-VERY buggy and not very user friendly at the moment (probably fixable in patches soon though)
- There's no backup system, so ATM you're the only cop in town
-animations, drivng physics and pursuits don't really work properly.
-tasers make people hover in the air for a minute (???)

So overall, if you're a fan of games such as SWAT 4 and GTA 4's LCPDFR mod, i'd recommend you give it a try after a few patches. For the dev's first PC release, it's pretty decent, with a good graphics/sound options menu.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Enforcer: Police Crime Action is an indie police simulator made by a very small team in Brazil.
It is a welcome addition to steam as we have very few police simulators on the store.
The game can be described as a mixture of The Sims, GTA and a little LA Noire. For most of the game you will be patrolling the map in a cruiser of your choice (Squad car, unmarked, SUV) pulling over drivers, doing breathalyzer tests, setting up roadblocks and doing stop and checks, responding to violent crime calls (such as burgalarys and drug deals).

The other half of the game is when you are off duty, you will be eating food, watching TV and sleeping to get your characters needs back up so you can head back out on duty.
There is also some small customization as you can buy furniture for your house and switch out your characters clothing (very little clothing choice as of now.)

The game offers a realistic" mode
date: which basically means your character has one life
recommended: if you create a character and get shot and killed
hoursPlayed: you won't respawn
voteText: that will be the end of that character. This mode makes you play carefully when responding to violent crimes
helpfulPercent: and is fun to see how long you can keep your character alive.\n\nThe game is definately rough around the edges with jagged animations and sometimes hilarious bugs (See flying cars and hilarious AI car accidents) the devs are doing a top notch job in taking these bugs out and are also adding new features daily
votesHelpful: but if you can't handle these types of bugs and rough edges
votesTotal: I wouldn't recommend buying this game.\n\nI really do hope that the devs continue to update this game and add new features
votesFunny: as it has potential to be a real gem
commentsCount: I also hope they add paid DLC so we can continue to support it.\n\nOverall Enforcer: Police Crime Action is a solid
column16: fun little police simulator
column17: people who really enjoy the feel of being a LEO and upholding the law will like this game
column18:
however those of you who don't like bugs and are looking for fast paced car chases and gun fights probably won't enjoy this game.

I'm personally looking forward to seeing what the devs do with this game and what kind of DLC we will get.

[Edit] If you decide to buy this game you can use these two codes to unlock bonus vehicles - "greenbrute" "iamunmarked""

reviewText:
I love police games and have played many variations over the years. I was looking forward to purchasing this game and trying it out. Unfortunately, it's fallen not short, but extremely far from my expectations.

This game at best feels half done. From the graphics, the game play, and especially the driving almost nothing exactly feels right. The one thing they did try is attempting to give the player more options in how to catch those who break the law. Even this they did with a great shake.

Enforcer : Police Crime Action resembles GTA in it's works. You are a police officer who can switch on and off duty by changing clothes inside your house. The house and your clothing can be customized/purchased and a car can be purchased for your own personal use. When you start out without a car, you'll be getting around by cab fare. There are three main bars you need to worry about : stress, hunger, and energy. Stress can be relieved by sleeping or hanging out with relatives, while the other two are quite obvious in how to replenish. What the game sort of did right was the simplicity in choosing what to ask a suspect. For example, imagine me standing on the side of the road and I see a car. I press C to tell the car to pull over then interact with the person inside by pressing the right mouse button. Upon pressing this, I'm given a few options to choose, from asking the person to step out of the car to using a breathalyzer. The animations are basic and none vary from person to person. Some drivers will be intoxicated or some sort of reason will pop up for you to apprehend them. Although it be it the case, I will give the game kudos for adding decoration to the command menu. When setting up a road block, you are able to walk up to your car and pull out some cones. You can also set up a radar to catch speeders but your involvement in that is literally minimal. You set up the radar and that's as far as you go. You will be waiting until you've reached the goal amount or until you get interrupted by a call on the radio. The game is sort of stale for this reason and other users have mentioned this as well. When a call does come up, a little adrenaline rush comes up and so does excitement... only for so long. Upon arriving on the scene of the crime, you will not catch the perpetrators in the act. Rather, they will be somewhere in the area and it's up to you to ask people for suspicious activity. Approach a perpetrator without a gun cocked and you may be kissing the pavement reminding yourself for the next time to run around like an idiot everywhere with his gun drawn. The game tries to act like a cop game, but I don't know of a single cop willing to run around with their gun in their hand pointing them at everyone and telling everyone hands up. This is the other thing, the objectives for the day such as issuing tickets are fun (to an extent) but when you get a call and usually the outcome involves you firing at the suspect and calling an ambulance, there isn't much to brag about. In the game SWAT 4, suspects were unsure whether they wanted to surrender or not which put the player in a real hot seat and gave them a feeling what it was like to be an officer. Here, the scenario always ends up with a call to the paramedic. It is cool that they give you all sorts of options such as being able to call for a police pickup-up of a suspect or being able to tow a car, but even then options feel quite limited. You are able to stop and frisk anyone you see in the street, but again, it's very limited in how everything goes down. People will 99% of the time shoot at you when you answer to a call on the radio. When stopping people on the street, they will give up right away. If they drop anything while they put their hands up, you are able to collect the evidence. Doing jobs properly will result in acquiring more XP and $$. I should mention that cars do get out of the way when your sirens and lights are on. As an added bonus, you can use your turn signals and even put your hazard lights on.

Graphics are at best GTA 3 quality and sounds are as basic as you can get. There is no variation in sound as every bullet and siren will sound exactly the same. The game feels empty due to the lack of ambiance. Every map sections more or less resembles each other to the tee.

What's wrong with this game? Well quite a bit. Driving first and fore most is the stiffest I've ever seen in any game. Stopping doesn't really stop you and using the hand break will not get you to where you need to go within a turn. If you forget to turn your engine off, your car may start rolling away. AI will keep walking into you and will not try to avoid you, and sometimes will continue walking into a wall. The other drivers on the road have zero intelligence. When they are told to pull over, they will crash right into you or another car. Also, when you do get run over, you don't get ran over... you get pushed by the car. Apparently it's normal for a cement truck to push a person along like it's another day in Mr. Rogers neighborhood. Not only that, the game feels extremely empty. No one interacts, no one looks around funny, no one looks suspicious, no criminal is on scene upon arriving at a forced entry crime scene even if you're right next door to the crime.

I want to love this game and because I'm a hardcore police simulation fan I will play it sporadically, but as far as it goes, this game is only meant for people who have an extremely high tolerance and appreciation for this sort of genre.

Giving it anything better than this would certainly be a crime.

RATING : 6.0/10

(This game is definitely not worth it's stated price)

ScreenShots :
Every map resembles this type of scenery

A.I's do a pretty good job pretending you don't exist

Set up a solid roadblock complete with radar

You won't have to call the fire department ever because nothing will ever be on fire

The collision system is extremely basic in the game. I can't even give him a ticket for hitting my car

reviewText:
When i first played this game it was... Well, not good. Dont want to say it was awful.
I have come back to it after a few months and it has radically improved.

The graphics are not gorgeous. In fact they would not look out of place in early Xbox games at points. So if you are looking for good look this is not it. And frankly, asking for good graphics in something that is a simulation game of this type is just silly.

Which brings me to my next point: I have seen some mention that the game gets pretty dull after some time playing. They are not wrong. However, once again, this IS a sim game that attempts to simulate a real life job. And much like its counterparts in the career simulation genre, things are going to get repetetive at times. Just like a real life career. Anyone who has played a truck simulator will have hit that issue where they feel bored, even if you are a trucking fan, like me. And that is to say nothing of my second favourite Farming Simulator. Sorry but real policing is not all gun fights and car chases.

Bugs. It has some small ones that unless you are someone who is easily annoyed or bugged (Badum Tsh!) by such things, you will not notice them.

What you get here is something that attempts to bring you the day to day grind of a police officer. Even the boring stuff (Which i personally like to see and do) such as traffic policing.

Could this be better? Sure. But what it is right now is good considering the small time it has been around.

So, dont expect high octane chases, and movie style policing. Its a simulation. And dont expect AAA graphics.

reviewText: Wow, this is so unfinished it makes Temper Tantrum look like a triple A title.\n\nLet me tell you about Enforcer: Police Crime Action. After having no idea what the hell this was ( i got given it free for attending a event in London) i came home and was not really expecting much, Booted the game, the idea itself is interesting (not unique in anyway) but atleast intreseting. But Wow within litteraly seconds i was shocked at how bad the current state of this game is. Its like a half arssed student project. The models are awful, the animations are awful, the world iteslf makes no sense (its a 20 second drive from corner to corner of the city) The mission are boring such as - Place parking tickets on cars. The game gives you guns and everything at the start so theres no sense of progression, The world is bland and clearly just thrown together without a thought at all, there are around 20 meaningless people that walk the entire earth, the cutscenes dont render correctly and when they do there a left over assets in the background, if the cars hit the player they just bounce off (due to the player weighing more, because of lazy programming) this game is FILLED to the brim with Bugs, i fell off the map twice, litterally played this for 30 mins and will never touch again. Now i wouldent mind if this game was £1.99 or something, but £15. What a joke, this is a unfinished mess, and the devs care only about money not the quality of this piece of ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Please don't pass by this game due to graphics not being beautiful! This is a strangely addicting game.Yes, the graphics are not high beautiful graphics, but I love it like that because it can run on poor machines.There are a few bugs here and there, but it is a new game.

What I like:
High Speed chases- Occassionally cars refuse to stop and I have to chase them.
Eating, Stress & Rest- Its more than just a simulator, it has a bit of a life to it as well.
Multiple areas to search- I love all the areas to search

Dislike:
NO GPS- You can easily become lost, especially coming home.
Car is difficult to steer- They need to adjust the sensitivity on the car.It goes out of control too easily.


I definitely recommend this game.I've been playing it everyday.

enforcer police crime acton is a roleplay game where you play as the best of the best of the mvpd play as a male or femail as you solve every crime with a bullet instead of a arrest,

reviewText:
Amazing Concept, Sadly the game isn't quite there yet. It's been said by other reviews, but it really does feel like it's in early access and not quite finished. Apart from the floating cars, etc. mentioned by others, these are the things i found frustrating:
- Fuel consumption. Appears to be the same regardless of engine revs... when i first started, i got into my patrol car, and played around with the keys etc for 5 mins. In that 5 mins, my fuel went down to 70%! Just idling in the driveway! Did they install a lawnmower tank in the car?

- Refuelling - Apart from the lack of driveway access to the gas station which knocks 7-8% points off your damage just getting next to the fuel pump, Why do I have to pay for the gas? Maybe it's different in other parts of the world but where I come from, the police department pays for the fuel, Not the officer!

- Bad Drivers! So, I'm giving a ticket to the truck parked illegally and some bozo drives into my patrol car (which had its lights going parked up on the side of the road). So I pull the driver out, Pat him down and breathalise him and he comes back clean. So I arrest him and take him to the station and apparently i've arrested an innocent man! I guess its not against the law in mountain valley to not look where you're driving. I imagine the same thing would have happened had I arrested the 2 people in cars outside the police station who were sat stationary on the footpath driving into the concrete planter boxes... Innocent too I imagine..

Its an awesome concept. and has the posibility of being one of the greats.. but it needs work. I would not recommend it right now.. its a disappointment. If the developers actively listen to the reviews and make some changes that make the game a little more realistic (it is after all touted as a SIMULATOR not an arcade game) then I'd be happy to re-review.. but if like me, you ignore the reviews and buy it anyway, be prepared for a let down.

reviewText: My first Steam purchase mistake. This game needs a lot of polish before it can even be considered playable for the mac. My MBrP should be more than capable of running a game like Enforcer: Police Crime Action judging by the graphics of the game (which is tolerable - let's say it's like gta 3 with slightly worse animation) and yet I lag heavily in downtown areas where there are a lot of NPCs (even at the lowest settings). I have no idea what's wrong but obviously the game is not as optimized as it should be.\n\nMissions get very repetitive after a while and there are no helpful instructions whatsoever as to what you need to actually do to complete missions or even find your way back to your own home. If you're the type of gamer that likes police simulators then by all means go ahead and buy it. It'll just be a while before this game develops to the playable state you were expecting in the first place.

reviewText: Its not the worst game ever because you cant run over people, or go on a murderous rampage. Its a good game as its something that hasnt been done before, there isnt an open world cop game like this. It does need a few changes and fixes (PLZ ADD MODS! / STEAM WORKSHOP!) but after all that i say its worth it, perhaps not £11.99 but worth it gameplay wise, i can only recomend this to the guy who wants something new and is tired of GTA 5 and has had enough of the same, but if you are the guy that is stuck with COD forever and is level 945 on GTA 5 then this most likely isnt for you as you are just the kind of person who gets what is fed to you and is happy with it (nothing wrong with that i enjoy playing COD and GTA sometimes too) but i say that we should cut the game some slack and let it evolve a bit, let it grow and see where its going. Its something that hasnt been tried and we should respect that, may not be the best game ever but definitly might grow to something, just someone please stop running me over on GTA.

reviewText:
If you are tired of playing LCPDFR (GTA4 police mod) because it crashes or you have played it enough...

This is an awesme game. There are some major issues still. I think this game should be in early access.

The major isues are:

Big amount of bugs

Horrible steering

AI could be smarter

Bad fps. I get on my computer, even if it's not the best one, in maximum settings around 12fps.


Positive things:

Nice amount of missions, can get repetitive sometimes.

Nice and detailed sound effects

Ok graphics, you can compare them to GTA San Andreas.

Nice amount of vehicles (5 in total)

Overall is an OK game for now. The developers are still updating it. I consider it  a bit expensive for the graphics and content. I give it a 6/10

If you want to purchase a better police simulator, in my opinion, check out police 10 13 on steam greenlight.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Disclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by the developer for review purposes

Few words about the game
Enforcer: Police Crime Action is a a game that shows complete opposite side of GTA series - the righteous side of the law. You're in control of policeman, starting your career from the very bottom of it, showing us with lots of details how does the average life of law-enforcement officers looks like.

Advantages
Good, quite uniqe concept of game
Absorbing gameplay with tons of various missions and events
Sounds are done quite well and voicing of characters is predominantly very good, big +" for it
Control over your characters
date: whether on foot or by car
recommended:
is bit weird yet very responsive
Map is impressive thanks to its size and diversity
Disadvantages
Mechanics and physics of game are horribly... stiff I would say. There is almost no smoothness anywhere you look around
Graphics are kinda not satisfying as for 2014 release
After few in-game days
hoursPlayed:
it forces you to be always on duty as things that are out there to do are really limitet
Buggy and glitchy as all hell
Summary
Game is obviously highly unpolished but devs are constantly coming out with new updates to it

reviewText:
EDIT 30/10/2014 - The developers released an update and I must admit this game is slowly starting to grow on me after playing for a few more hours.
The developers are extremely honest and open about the game and are ready to make improvements with feedback from the community.
A second update is to be released today and I am looking forward to see what changes they have made and how it has been improved.


ORIGINAL REVIEW AT LAUNCH-

Total garbage in its current state.

The day/night cycle alone is an absolute joke. How long is a day in your world? 2 minutes?

When you are hungry an animation plays as if you were being stabbed along with a hideous sound effect that sounds like someone scraping a rusty knife against another rusty knife.

AWFUL!

Should definitely not be called a simulation because it's totally unrealistic and breaks the immersion itself continuously.

I had high hopes for this, but as of now I am very disappointed.

I only played for 30 minutes because the game is just terrible. Great idea, really bad execution.

Do yourself a favour and pick up a copy of gta4 and install the LCPD:FR mod. Now that's what I call a police simulator!

reviewText:
Before I wouldn't have bought this game for the £15. Seeing as it was half price I thought I'd give it a shot and I bought it. Great small game in short! If you are a fan LCPD:FR mod for GTA IV then I highly recommend this. Only played roughly 20 minutes of gameplay but I can tell you you'd love it. Bought it to also support the developers for doing a great job in this new genre.

If you get your kick from graphics then this may not be for you, I won't say they're terrible but more or less just look old.

I'm hoping for some sort of multiplayer coop, graphic update (or mod support), more vehicles/skins, animations, player models etc.

Quite impressed. Really recommend if this is up your street!

reviewText:
The Bad things :
-Car physics are just bad, but you will get used to it, at least you can use your car turning lights in this game.

reviewText:
This is fairly decent for the price. It has some very nice gameplay elements. It has the potential to expand and become better. Everything works well.

Pros  - Gameplay is decent. You work as a police officer, then when off duty, you get to enjoy personal time. meet with friends and family, eat, sleep, watch tv, use a computer. Its a nice mix.
- You get to customize your house and vehicles.
- You can Purchase new vehicles.
- The Realism is there, but it is wanting to be improved.

Cons - Driving is a little touchy, Graphics seem blury and blocky sometimes, but all managable.
- The Controls are a little fiddly
- The AI vehicles & People randomly spawn in front of you when your racing to an incident.
- Traffic doesn't flow nice.

I've enjoyed the game so far. I do hope to see more improvements.

reviewText:
This is a game Ive been looking for, for sometime now. I really love the the game as an idea, so far there have been a few bugs. Now i paid for the game knowing there were bugs and there might be some problems. IF you buy the game keeping an open mind then you should be very pleased. I would how ever like to see/ hear more on the radio. The same few things being said over and over does get very old quick, so i just pull up a real police scanner for the noise. also the hunger and tired thing, i understand maybe a flashing message but something that locks you up so you cant move is not realistic at all,

that being said also i would like yo see the game opened up for the steam workshop i think it would add alot more to the game and also take alot of the pressure off of the team and allow the community to mod it here and there to make it better, like more cars, diffrent types of calls, more actions when it comes to interacting with the world.

I really enjoy the game and can see what it can/will become. I hope with a few more months of work this will be the game ive dreamed of for years

reviewText: Already addicted. This game has a very realistic feel to it, and has many different features that you can do; For example you can walk up to an civilian NPC and ask them if they have seen someone with a warrant, if they seem drunk you can ask them to take a breathealyzer. You can also check the NPCs for drugs and weapons along with many other things. Somtimes you're hiding near a highway with radars ready to catch speeders. Sometimes im patroling watching for gang/drug activity. The only downside to this game is that the graphics are terrible, they're similiar to the ps2's graphics and have similar graphics to GTA: San Andreas, but I hardly even notice the bad graphics and they're easily overlooked. This game is especially impressive considering only FOUR men came together to make this game. I would defintely recommend this game.

reviewText: Repetative is the first word that comes to mind when I think of this game. In the trailers it seems as if there are cool crimes to arrest people for such as robbery, murder, or kidnapping. While ther are these crimes that occur they RARELY happen. In the mean time there is really not much to do but the boring repetative stop and frisk, or pull over a breathalize. The controls for this game are a whole other problem. The car is near impossible to steer which wouldn't be a problem if you didn't have to pay your money that you made in the game to repair it. Overall, I think that this game started out with a good concept in mind but with a lack of variety and hard to use controls, the idea never blossomed.
